message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the patient's history of alcoholism and laboratory findings, the most likely diagnosis is alcoholic hepatitis. Among the options, only option (D) is a characteristic histopathologic finding in alcoholic hepatitis, where "Mallory bodies" (cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin) are found in hepatocytes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and laboratory findings suggest alcoholic hepatitis, which can lead to formation of cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin on liver biopsy. T-lymphocyte infiltration is more commonly seen in autoimmune hepatitis, while macronodular cirrhosis suggests long-standing liver disease. Periportal necrosis is a feature of acute viral hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of alcoholism, elevated ALT and AST levels, and symptoms suggest alcoholic liver disease. Cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin are a characteristic finding of alcoholic hepatitis on liver biopsy. T-lymphocyte infiltration is seen in autoimmune hepatitis, macronodular cirrhosis in alcohol-induced cirrhosis, and periportal necrosis in viral hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of alcoholism and his liver function tests are elevated, indicating alcoholic hepatitis. The cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin are characteristic of alcoholic hepatitis. T-lymphocyte infiltration and periportal necrosis are more characteristic of viral hepatitis, and macronodular cirrhosis is a late finding in alcoholic liver disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and laboratory findings suggest alcoholic hepatitis. Cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin are characteristic of alcoholic hepatitis. T-lymphocyte infiltration is seen in autoimmune hepatitis. Macronodular cirrhosis and periportal necrosis are not specific to alcoholic hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of alcoholism and laboratory findings suggest alcoholic hepatitis. Alcoholic hepatitis can cause the formation of Mallory bodies, which are cytoplasmic inclusion bodies containing keratin. Therefore, option (D) Cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin is the most likely histopathologic finding on a liver biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history, clinical symptoms, and laboratory findings suggest alcoholic hepatitis. Among the options, only cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin are associated with alcoholic hepatitis, called Mallory bodies. T-lymphocyte infiltration and periportal necrosis are associated with viral hepatitis, while macronodular cirrhosis suggests late-stage liver disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of alcoholism and laboratory findings point towards alcoholic liver disease. Among the options, only cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin can be found in alcoholic liver disease. T-lymphocyte infiltration is common in viral hepatitis and autoimmune hepatitis, macronodular cirrhosis is seen in advanced cirrhosis, and periportal necrosis is seen in acute viral hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of alcoholism and elevated liver enzymes suggest alcoholic hepatitis. Among the options, only cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin are associated with alcoholic hepatitis on liver biopsy. T-lymphocyte infiltration is seen in autoimmune hepatitis, macro nodular cirrhosis is seen in late-stage alcoholic liver disease, and periportal necrosis is seen in viral hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of alcoholism, laboratory findings of elevated ALT and AST suggests alcoholic hepatitis. Cytoplasmic inclusion bodies with keratin are commonly seen in alcoholic hepatitis. The other options are not typical findings in alcoholic hepatitis.
